text:
Hi guys! I'm Laura Vitale. And on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I'm going to show

you my recipe for French Dip Beef Sandwich,
or French Dip Sandwich, however you call it.

This has gotten requested so often around
here. I always read your comments down below

so I'm always excited when I find that there
are certain items that I just haven't made.

And I make them all the time, I just can't
believe I haven't shared them with you yet.

So if you have any comments, if you want to
leave any comments down below with recipes

you want to see, make sure you do leave them
down there because I do read all of your comments

and it would be great that I could find that
person that made that special request.

The ingredients you will need for the base
- the sauce and the meat in this case - you're

going to need a good rump roast, that's what
I'm using today. You can use any kind of meat

that you prefer to use with the sandwich,
but that's what I always use. I've got some

onions that I've sliced, and as you can see
they're not super thin but that's because

I don't want them to disintegrate in the sauce.
I've got some onion flakes - dried onion flakes

- I've got some dried Italian seasoning, lots
of chopped garlic, I've got got some soy sauce,

Worcestershire sauce, vegetable oil, salt
and pepper, you'll need beef stock, and a

beer. That's all you'll need for right now.
When we go on to assembling it and everything,
I'll show you the remaining ingredients.

I've got some vegetable oil in there getting
really nice and hot because I want to sear

this bad boy. We're going to make this in
our crock pot so it can cook all day and your

home will just be infused with incredible
aromas - I'm out of peppercorns in there - and

a little bit of salt. You don't have to put
too much salt because we are going to be adding

the soy sauce and Worcestershire and they're
really salty and I don't want this to become

overwhelming. So now that my pan is nice and
hot, I'm going to put this seasoned-side down.

I'm just going to let that cook just a couple
minutes all around or until it's really nice
and brown.

Just browned out on both sides for just a
couple minutes. Make sure you put it on a

clean plate. Now, in the same skillet with
that remaining vegetable oil, I'm going add

my onions because I want to develop a little
bit of color on these onions, in fact I'm

going to turn this to about high heat because
I don't want the onions to cook down, I just

want them to develop a little bit of color
because color - food plus color equals really
good flavor.
There you go.

Now, let that go for a minute, and in the
meantime, let's get started on building the
juice, the au jus.

This is going to be just unbelievable. I've
got some stock here and as you know, I use

water with this beef base. It's not going
to dissolve because it's not hot but that's
okay.
Whoa!

That's quite all right, it will dissolve once
it all cooks together.

I'm going to add about a cup of beer. You
want to use a good lager, a nice dark beer.

I'm using a Yuengling because, well it's close
to home. Save the rest for the cook - cook's

treat, you always have to have one - and then
you've got your dehydrated onion and your
Italian seasoning.

Now, I know a lot of recipes for this specific
recipe call for an onion soup packet. You

know me, I don't use very much of the packets,
and you absolutely can, but I just find that

I can use dehydrated onions plus really good
saut√©ed colored onions and it just give you

an amazing flavor. And I know that so many
of you are not from the U.S. so it would be

a product that you wouldn't be able to get,
so dehydrated onion or some onion powder will
do the job just fine.

Lots of garlic, and then I'm going to add
equal parts of soy and Worcestershire and

black pepper. I'm not adding any salt because,
again, everything is pretty salty in there,

the Worcestershire and the soy sauce is pretty
salty, and you can always adjust things at

the very end if you want to. But I'm just
going to give this a quick little mix to blend
everything together.
Whew!

Alright, let me tend to my onions. I just
want some brief color. See that? That's just

going to give you amazing flavor and you can
cut them really thin if you want to or leave

them a bit more thick like I did, because
this is going to cook on low for about 8 hours.

If I had cut them any thinner, they would
completely disintegrate, which are going to

still be delicious, but I want to be able
to get a bit more texture out of them if I

can. But I'm just going to let these go for
about one more minute and we'll be done.

These look good enough. I'm going to put that
into the bottom of my slow cooker here. They

smell incredible already. Now give me those
on a sandwich and some melted cheese and it

would be delightful. Put that beef in there
with that juice. That mixture that we put
together - pour that right over everything.
Oh, this is going to be amazing.

Trust me when I tell you that the aroma in
your house once this gets going - you'll thank
me.
I know you will.

Okay, this is going to go into my sleeve - into
my slow cooker. I'm going to turn this on

for about 6 to 8 hours on low, or about 4
to 6 hours on high. I'm going to put this

on low for 8 hours. It is going to be melt-in-your-mouth
tender and when we sandwich it, in a deliciously

golden-buttered toasted bun with cheese - just
trust me, it's going to be amazing.
All right, in she goes.

This beautiful baby was in my crock pot for
almost 8 hours. I did have it on low. Now,

what I did was I took it out and I let it
rest for about 20 minutes or so. I also took

a small ladle and just kind of scooped out
as much fat as I could from the very top because
I don't want a lot of the fat.

Now, this is going to - if you just try to
pull this apart, it would just pull apart

with no problem - so if you wanted to, you
could pull this apart. Or, if you want to

slice it, you slice against the grain. So
I'm going to slice it this way, and you can

make your slices as thick or as thin as you
like, and I'm going to put them on this plate.

Once you have your meat all sliced up or shredded
or whatever, I'm going to just assemble one

so that I can show you how it goes because
I've got friends coming around in just a bit

and we're going to assemble more when they
get here.

I like to take a little of melted butter and
I like to brush it on the inside of a nice

little crusty hoagie roll with it open like
so. I'm going to pop this under the broiler

just to get it really nice and toasted. In
the meantime, if you want to, and you should

take all this meat and dump it right back
into these juices. I'm not going to do that

until my friends come around only because
I don't these to get too soggy, but I'm just

going to pop this under there for just a quick
second and I'll show you what it looks like
when it's all nice and golden and toasty.

While my bread is toasting up, I'm going to
quick pull together a little horseradish sauce

that I always serve with these sandwiches,
or anytime I make any roast beef or prime

rib. I've got some mayo, sour cream, tons
of chopped chives, I've got some horseradish

- this is just prepared horseradish you buy
in a little jar - coarse mustard, Dijon mustard.

To that I'm going to add just a dash of Worcestershire
sauce, a good grinding of black pepper, and

I'm going to just mix all this together to
combine and just like that you have the best
creamy horseradish sauce ever.

Alright, now I just take some pieces of this
gorgeous beef, dunk it into the juices, because
obviously you want to dunk.
Look at that.

And those onions. It's just, it goes beyond
me as just a delicious sandwich. I can't even

describe to you how incredible this is. I
like to really pile it up there, but you know,

you can do as much or as little as you want.
Then, a couple pieces of provolone, Swiss,

whatever tickles your fancy, and pop this
back into the oven. You can, if you want to,

do a layer of the sauce before you add the
beef. I always serve the sauce on the side

so that people can put as much or as little
as they want. So I'm going to pop this back
in and then we'll eat it.

Look at that baby. Ah! Heaven! Now that - and
you just take the top, and you squoodge, and

then you cut, and then you open, and then
you dunk - I know, I'm torturing you, and
I do apologize.

Cheese. A girl's gotta do what a girl's gotta
do!
That is out of this world.
I mean, really.

As embarrassing as this is to say, this is
my snack before my friends come here.

I'm telling you, this is so worth making for
any occasion, and the best part about it is

that leftovers taste amazing, so make the
full thing of it, keep it in the fridge, keep

the sauce and the beef separate, and then
heat them up, dunk, put them in a sandwich,
I mean it's heaven. It really is heaven.
I know,
I should really pace myself but...

Go to LauraInTheKitchen.com to get this recipe.
I hope you've enjoyed spending time with me

and, as always, I will see you next time.
If you make this recipe, make sure you follow

me on Twitter and social media and whatnot
and send me the pictures so I can see it.

I'm going to stop blabbering and go back to
eating. I'll see you next time.
Bye bye.
